data.source: World Bank LSMS (UP–Bihar) Village and Household Questionnaires; primary field survey (1997–1998)
data.wave_or_subset: 120 villages (63 in Uttar Pradesh, 57 in Bihar); 2,250 households; some analyses also use 2001 Census village-level irrigation metrics
data.notes: Villages are classified by dominant caste based on majority land ownership. Historical caste dominance is treated as plausibly exogenous given minimal caste-based migration. Contextual historical records are used for background.

method.description: The study exploits cross-village variation in dominant caste (based on land ownership) in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar to compare agricultural outcomes and irrigation access. It estimates OLS models of agricultural income/yields on indicators for village caste dominance and water market participation, and uses IV (2SLS) to address endogeneity of water-buyer status with instruments capturing natural water access and village area. Controls include education, land ownership, land quality, and crop choices. The analysis examines groundwater market functioning, especially interactions between water-buyer status and low-caste dominated villages.
steps: Define village dominant caste by the caste that owns the majority of land and classify villages as high-caste dominated or low-caste (BAC/OBC/SC) dominated.

Assemble LSMS 1997–1998 village and household data for UP and Bihar; construct outcomes (agricultural income, crop income per acre, yields) and key covariates (education, land ownership/quality, crop choices, irrigation access).
Tabulate and compare village characteristics and irrigation access across caste-dominated village types; document pump ownership, water buyers/sellers, and groundwater market activity.

Estimate OLS regressions of agricultural income/yields on low-caste-dominated village indicator, water-buyer status, and their interaction, controlling for education, land ownership, land quality, and crop choices.
Address potential endogeneity of water-buyer status using IV (2SLS) with instruments: access to natural water sources and village area; re-estimate key specifications.

Conduct robustness and additional analyses: examine lower-caste subsamples, same-caste trading patterns, compare land quality and infrastructure, and use 2001 Census irrigation measures to corroborate irrigation differences.
method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression; Instrumental Variables (2SLS) regression
method.outcome_variable: Agricultural income (crop income per acre) and crop yields
method.independent_variables: Indicator for low-caste dominated village; water-buyer status; interaction term (low-caste village × water-buyer); tubewell ownership; irrigation access; caste composition
method.control_variables: Education/literacy, land ownership/operated area, land value (land quality), crop choices

results.summary: Lower-caste households achieve higher agricultural income and yields in low-caste dominated villages, largely due to better access to private irrigation via functioning groundwater markets. The interaction between living in a low-caste dominated village and being a water buyer is strongly positive in both OLS and IV estimates. Low-caste dominated villages have higher irrigated area shares and higher tubewell ownership among lower castes. Alternative explanations such as land quality, infrastructure, and tenancy do not account for the observed differences.
